text: hello this is chef john from food wishes
comm with roasted apple and parsnip soup
that's right it's been a long time since
I've done one of these comforting and
middle of winter soups but in fairness
it has been a long time since it's been
in the middle winter but anyway this
really did come out quite well so I'm
looking forward to sharing it with you
and while technically this is a food
wish it was actually inspired by a trip
to a local gastro pub where I enjoyed a
beautiful bowl of parsnip soup and asked
the server what was in it and he said
roasted apples parsnips and a potato and
I thought to myself I think I could make
that and as it turns out I could so
check it out this was as easy as it was
delicious
so for step one we're going to prep our
parsnips and apples for roasting and to
do that I'm gonna peel the parsnips and
then we'll cut them into some roasted
low sized pieces keep in mind this stuff
is going to be blended so the exact
sizes aren't that important although we
do want everything to kind of roast at
the same rate but as long as we're close
you're good and one thing to pay
attention to when you're trimming
parsnips they can have kind of a tougher
woody center sometimes had these smaller
ones it's not that noticeable but when
you are cutting one of these bigger ones
you want to pay attention it can
actually be quite tough and fibrous
sometimes that causes people to lose
control the knife and they cut
themselves in the business we call that
a parsnip slip so please cut carefully
and since I'm not planning to strain the
soup later if it does feel extra tough
and fibrous I will sometimes cut those
pieces out so you make the call on that
that's up to you you are the dwight
shrute of your vegetables and fruit and
then once we have those cut up we will
transfer those out to a foil lined
baking sheet and move on to prepping the
apple and you don't have to but I'm
going to peel my apples like I said I
prefer not to have to strain this later
and the last thing you want when you're
eating a beautiful silky soup is tough
little microscopic pieces of apple peels
stuck to the back of your throat nobody
wants that so I'm going to peel the
Apple cut the core out and then slice
them up like this and we'll add that to
our parsnips and then before we roast
this we'll give this a little drizzle of
olive oil maybe a little bit more than a
little it will also give that a generous
sprinkling of kosher salt and then let's
give those a little toss to make sure
they're coated with that oil and at that
point we will put those in the center of
a 450 degree oven for about 30 minutes
or until they look like this the edges
should be pretty well caramelized and
everything should be pretty tender
of course you can make soup without
roasting the vegetables first but by
roasting you really concentrate those
flavors and I think you get a much
better final product but anyway once our
parsnips and apples are roasted nicely
we will transfer those into our soup pot
along with one russet potato that I
peeled and cut nate's and then we go
ahead and fill this up with broth or
water or a combination in fact that's
what I'm doing I'm going to add about a
quart of chicken broth and a couple cups
of water and of course we're using cold
fresh water and we'll give that a little
stir and then stop me if you've heard
this one before but what we're going to
do is bring this up to a boil on high
heat and then of course we'll back the
heat down to maintain a nice steady
simmer and we'll simmer that for about
thirty minutes or until everything's
very very tender and completely
blendable now of course we already
roasted the vegetables so those should
be no problem but definitely double
check your chunks of potato and when
those are nice and soft we are ready to
blend and I'm going to use my stick
blender also known as an immersion
blender just because it's so fast and
easy but if you don't have one no
problem you can just carefully process
this in a couple batches in a regular
blender as long as you get it really
really smooth you're ready for the next
step so we're going to blend that up and
then what we'll do is we'll grab a spoon
and taste this but not for taste
for texture because right here is where
you're going to decide if you're going
to strain it or not so give it a taste
and if it's beautifully silky and smooth
like mine was you do not need to strain
it however if it seems a little fibrous
for whatever reason take an extra minute
and put this through a fine strainer and
return it to the pot and at that point
we're ready to move on to the final
steps at this point we'll stir in our
cream beautiful beautiful heavy cream
and all its thirty six percent butterfat
glory and while we're stirring that in
we're sort of thinking about the texture
and after you stir the cream in if you
do want to thin it out a little bit you
can add another splash of broth which is
what I did right here I mean I like a
thick soup but I don't like too thick of
a soup so I stirred in some broth and
once that soup has come back up to
temperature and it's nice and piping hot
you're ready to serve except of course
for the most important step we have to
taste for salt and seasoning all right
95% of all soups that people think are
terrible are simply under salted so I
season mine with some salt
I also snuck in a little pinch of
cayenne to bring out all the other
flavors and once your soup is seasoned
to your idea of perfection then finally
we're ready to grab a ladle
serve this up and right here you can get
a really good look at that final texture
all right not too thick not too thin for
me that's just perfect I want it to be
rich and satisfying but I don't want it
to be like a bowl of pureed vegetables
and at that point we will let it lit up
into some hot bowls and as soup really
is so good you could eat a plain but
don't you're going to want to garnish
this with some croutons
but not just any croutons you're going
to want to use some blue cheese croutons
yes thanks to a recent technological
breakthrough I've discovered a way to
infuse croutons with blue cheese which
were just beyond amazing on this soup
and I'm happy to announce I will be
showing you how to do that in the next
video so stay tuned for that and then
for the last final touches I decided to
crumble on a little more blue cheese and
a pinch of fresh chive and that roasted
apple and parsnip soup is done and for a
humble winter soup it was fantastic as
you may know parsnips have a delicious
earthy flavor with just that little
anise flavor in the background and of
course the apples are providing a little
sweetness as did our roasting process
and of course everything is set off by
those crunchy slightly salty somewhat
funky croutons just a gorgeous
collection of tastes and textures I mean
this stuff was so good it'll totally
make you forget that after lunch you're
going to have to go outside and spend an
hour shoveling the driveway set the chef
in San Francisco where it's currently 68
degrees but anyway the point was this
was amazing so I really do hope you give
it a try head over to food wishes calm
for all the ingredient amounts and more
info as usual and as always enjoy
you
